info.game_comments:
Jason McCune game 3.

(Alex: This is going to be an easy half-hour for me because we have an entire category on former President Clinton, and all of the clues in that category are going to be delivered by this man.)
(Bill Clinton: Hi, I'm Bill Clinton.)

(1, 1).clue: This Greek mathematician's 13-volume work "Elements" is the basis for modern-day geometry

(2, 1).clue: Talk about rapid transit! This city's monorail travels from Westlake Center to the Space Needle in 90 seconds

(4, 1).clue: In the 1890's British police in Bengal, India were the first to use these "digital" impressions to identify criminals

(5, 1).clue: Catchphrase for painter or poet suffering malnourishment to create beauty

(6, 1).clue: Weatherman Willard Scott was the first actor to don the clown makeup of this fast food funnyman

(1, 2).clue: The diameter of a circle always passes through this point

(2, 2).clue: The Place D'Armes, a square in New Orleans, was renamed to honor this hero of the Battle of New Orleans

(4, 2).clue: Often indecent or unsightly, it's scratching, scribbling, or painting words on walls or vehicles

(5, 2).clue: It's the slightly out-of-date device seen here

(6, 2).clue: In "It", he wrote about a monster disguised as a demonic clown named Pennywise

(1, 3).clue: It's the side of a right triangle that is opposite the right angle

(2, 3).clue: You'll have a whale of a good time in Lahaina, a former whaling port on this Hawaiian island

(4, 3).clue: It's the "barrier" term for a person who buys & sells stolen goods from a burglar

(5, 3).clue: Quasi-rheumatic discomfort in the limbs, especially during adolescence

(6, 3).clue: On TV Damon Wayans played this irascible clown who "don't play that"

(1, 4).clue: An obtuse angle is one that is greater than 90 degrees but less than this

(2, 4).clue: The GREAT EscAPE is a simulated tropical forest full of apes at this state capital's zoo; sounds "OK" to me

(3, 4).clue: Led the first bombing raid on Tokyo in World War II

(4, 4).clue: In his career, this defense lawyer has defended Sam Sheppard, Patty Hearst, & the Boston Strangler

(5, 4).clue: Object at right in the photo seen here

(6, 4).clue: (Sofia & Sarah make complete fools of themselves in silent-movie mode as Alex reads the clue.) This term for the type of comedy seen here comes from a rod used by 16th-century clowns to smack others on the behind

(1, 5).clue: This quadrilateral has 2 parallel sides that are unequal in length

(2, 5).clue: Visiting the Hayden planetarium in New York City? Don't miss the American museum of this--it's right next door

(4, 5).clue: Printed beneath a wide-open eye, "We never sleep" is the motto of this private detective agency

(5, 5).clue: In 1990 Justice Brennan wrote one when he disagreed with the Cruzan v. Missouri decision

(6, 5).clue: Seen here, this Italian director of the 1971 film "The Clowns" ran away to join the circus as a child

(1, 1).clue: (Bill Clinton kicks things off.) I earned this nickname from the way my campaign was revived in the 1992 New Hampshire primary

(2, 1).clue: Rembrandt turned this engraving method involving acid into an art form

(3, 1).clue: Yeah, Mr. Barrow, Ms. Parker, I see your V-8 from this company needs bodywork, but I don't do bulletproofing

(4, 1).clue: Cranberries grow on these, like grapes

(5, 1).clue: Colonel Sanders wore one on his chin

(6, 1).clue: The cloning of dinosaur DNA propels this 1993 movie blockbuster

(1, 2).clue: (President Clinton delivers our next clue.) In the first Presidential trip to Africa, I met with this President & visited his old jail

(2, 2).clue: (Sofia stands next to a famous statue on a fountain.) This famous statue by Daniel Chester French was dedicated by Ulysses S. Grant in 1875

(3, 2).clue: All righty, Mr. Lindbergh, this plane is all gassed up...should be good for 3,600 miles, give or take

(4, 2).clue: Cranberry growers bring in millions of these insects to pollinate the flowers

(5, 2).clue: (Sofia of the Clue Crew cleans a window with an interesting gadget.)  It's the implement I'm using to clean the window

(6, 2).clue: Born in Austria, he starred in "The 6th Day", a 2000 film in which clones attempt to take over the world

(1, 3).clue: (The 42nd U.S. President delivers our next clue.) In July 1995, following better cooperation on the MIA issue, I normalized U.S. relations with this country

(2, 3).clue: Roger Fry of the Met coined this term for the work of artists like Cezanne & Gauguin

(3, 3).clue: Right-o, Colonel Lawrence, your brough superior one of these is ready to go-just a smidge of a wobble in the front

(4, 3).clue: Rice is grown in a paddy; cranberries in a watery area known by this 3-letter term

(5, 3).clue: In Gaelic legend the wailings of this old woman spirit outside a house foretell a death within

(6, 3).clue: A 2'8'' clone played by Verne Troyer appears as pure concentrated evil in this 1999 hit comedy sequel
(6, 3).correct response: "Austin Powers II: The Spy Who Shagged Me"

(1, 4).clue: (The former President delivers our next clue.) The $20 billion loan that I arranged for this country in 1995 was paid back 3 years early

(2, 4).clue: This author wrote a pamphlet supporting Manet as well as a letter supporting Dreyfus

(3, 4).clue: Well, Mr. Hur, it looks like this vehicle needs a new axle; and you might think about adding some spikes

(4, 4).clue: Most harvested cranberries are sold by this company co-founded by Marcus Urann, the Cranberry King

(5, 4).clue: The name of this literary slave owner became associated with any cruel taskmaster

(6, 4).clue: Harrison Ford hunts down & kills clones called Replicants in this 1982 sci-fi classic

(1, 5).clue: (Former President Clinton wraps things up for us.) This program providing financial aid for education was created with the 1993 signing of the National & Community Service Trust Act

(2, 5).clue: Dante Gabriel Rossetti wanted to take art back to "pre"- this renaissance master born in 1483

(3, 5).clue: General Guderian, we'll need to rustproof the tracks on this tank--charge it to the Fuhrer?

(4, 5).clue: In "Strawberry Fields Forever", John Lennon intoning the name of this dish, has been misheard as "I buried Paul"

(5, 5).clue: Used to express scorn or disbelief, it's one of Scarlett O'Hara's favorite expressions

(6, 5).clue: Construction worker Michael Keaton clones himself to get more done in this 1996 comedy

(0, 0).clue: "Il Muto" & "Don Juan Triumphant" are shows within this show that premiered on Broadway in 1988
